newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico Cetes rate ends up on speculative deals.
newsitem.headline: Mexico Cetes rate ends up on speculative deals.

text.p: Mexican overnight Cetes rates inched up 20 basis points to close at 23.50 percent on Thursday after zigzagging through the session on speculative trading, dealers said.

"The conditions are ripe for rates to be lower than this, but the day saw much speculation," a trader said, who underlined the fact by noting government paper changed hands at an average of 22.90 percent during the session.
Traders said a decline in March inflation and news that sovereign and Brady bonds will trade in Mexico from April 22 heralded a downturn in interest rates.

"Right now, inflation news and the forthcoming trading of sovereign debt in Mexico gives the markets good cause to react and break the upward trend it has shown in recent sessions," another trader said.
Banco de Mexico announced on Wednesday that consumer prices rose 1.24 percent in March, compared with a rise of 1.68 percent in February.
The central bank drained 6.601 billion pesos from the market through six secondary auctions, which it assigned at rates of between 25.34-24.88 percent.
Overnight rates on bank paper ended up 20 basis points at 25.50 percent.
June Cetes futures closed down one centavo to 78.02 pesos on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
Liquidity of 2.538 billion pesos was scheduled to return to the system on Friday from prior central bank participation.
